contentrichtext.text: :''"Maohi" can also refer to the indigenous people of [[French Polynesia]], also known as [[Tahitians]].'' In the [[Polynesian mythology]] of Tahiti and other islands of [[French Polynesia]], the '''Maohi''' (''Mā’ohi'' in [[tahitian language]]) are the ancestors of the [[Polynesia]]n peoples. The term can also be a reference to normal every day people, just as [[Māori people|Māori]] is accepted among native or indigenous people in [[Aotearoa]], [[New Zealand]] or [[Avaiki]], [[Cook Islands]] as the way they describe themselves. Te Ao Maohi - the Maohi world - as an expression coined by [[Oscar Temaru]] gives an example of this.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Indigenous World 2005|author= Diana Vinding|year=2005|publisher=IWGIA|pages=262|isbn=87-91563-05-4}}</ref> ==See also== *[[Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organization]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Tahiti and Society Islands mythology}} [[Category:Tahiti and Society Islands mythology]] {{Oceania-myth-stub}} {{FrenchPolynesia-stub}}
